model_output:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a field that focuses on creating machine-based intelligence, replicating human-like problem-solving abilities. The Turing Test, proposed in the 1950s [3], serves as a benchmark for AI evaluation, assessing whether responses are of human or machine origin. Theoretical foundations of AI can be traced back to various definitions and tests of intelligence developed by psychologists [6]. For instance, Binet's test results were a good predictor of children's academic performance in the early 1900s [6]. In the 2000s, a universal intelligence measure was mathematically formalized to produce a general measure of intelligence for arbitrary machines [6]. Over time, the definition of AI has evolved to encompass different approaches and technologies. For example, Expert Systems were one of the earlier research fields in AI [4], while recent advancements involve Large Language Models (LLMs) and vision language models (VLMs) [2]. The technical evolution of LLMs has been significant, with notable examples like ChatGPT [3]. However, it is crucial to address ethical considerations as AI continues to evolve. For instance, the EU Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI emphasize preventing and mitigating abuse of AI systems [5]. The imitation game proposed by Turing in 1950 considered the question of machine intelligence based on human-like conversation over a text channel [5]. References:
